description:
I've been coming to this little hidden gem for over 10 years. 
Every single thing I've ever had here has been delicious. 
My current favorites are the basil stuffed eggplant, the pumpkin curry, and especially the banana leaf trout. 
I normally avoid Thai food as it is usually too sweet...but not here. The flavors are nice and balanced. 
The service is always friendly and gracious. 
This is my favorite Thai food in San Francisco
author: Nilu r.

description:
We got take out from Jitlada and the food was really good!

We ordered the green curry chicken, chicken pad kee mao, and eggplant with tofu. I really loved the texture of the noodles in the pad kee mao. In the green curry, the chicken was perfectly done, I just wish there was a little less coconut milk and more green curry taste, and it's really hard to go with any eggplant dish so no complaints there.

Next time I'll definitely want to try out the tom yum soup since that's usually my go to dish, but for now I feel like the three dishes that I got are a good sign that this place is a solid choice to go with if you're craving Thai food.
author: Gita r.

description:
Jitlada is a small hole in the wall that mustn't be passed up!

To preface this review, my boyfriend and I just recently moved to the area and wanted to find a good take out restaurant...and we sure did! 

Obviously I cannot speak to the service because we got it to-go, but the food is so tasty, we definitely will be repeat customers.

We ordered the yellow beef curry, chicken pad thai, and the golden baskets. Everything was so far beyond our expectations! Some of the best thai food I've had in terms of price and quality, and an added bonus - quantity!

Definitely recommend, and 100% will be back. See you soon!
author: Jamie J.

description: It was my last night in San Fran and was staying in to try to get an early night.  I ordered the chicken pad thai and the gaend deang (gang dang).  Both are very very good!  Docked one star because typically a curry/stew type dish, such as the gaend deang, would come with white rice.  This didn't, so be sure to order white rice separately to sop up all that goodness.
author: Mona B.

description:
Here's a more traditional take on Thai food that's been a mainstay in J-Town for as long as I can remember, and we all know that's a long time. Actually it's been about 17 years according to their website with the same chef/owner, Chef Pai, who comes from Thailand where she learned all her cooking techniques. In other words, there ain't no fusion confusion here. Consequently it was never the 'it' place to go to among the Yelperati, rather a warhorse that has survived its semi-hidden location on Buchanan while fashion-forward ramen and BBQ eateries rise and fall.

I came here after a long lapse since my last visit for a late dinner and found it empty except for one large, loud group of young Asian women who were grousing about the lack of quality men in the city. I told them they might have better luck opening Grindr accounts. OK, I didn't but I felt like sharing that 'Sleepless in Seattle' statistic where they concluded they had a better chance of being killed by a terrorist than getting married. But back to me as I ordered the $9 Bangkok Salad, a refreshing mix of greens, cashews, carrots, tomatoes, and cucumber slices, all of the ingredients tossed in a soy sesame vinaigrette (photo: http://bit.ly/2Mg0Uos).

It was delicious but not quite enough to stand alone for my pronounced appetite, so I ordered the $13 Sam-Sa-Hai, a plate of chicken, sautéed baby corn, zucchini, mushrooms, snow peas, red peppers, scallions, and cashews in their house special ginger sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2MkYc0Z). I think what separated this dish from normal stir fries was the piquant flavor of the ginger, obviously something Chef Pai has perfected over the years and hasn't changed since. And why should she? I don't think she's gunning for another Michelin Star like Kin Khao. I think it's fine the way it is. But jeez, get a Grindr account, will ya?

FOOD - 4 stars...good, no-fuss traditional Thai dishes
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...would-be quiet spot except for the cacophonous gaggle of girls
SERVICE - 4 stars...very quiet and attentive despite the noise
TOTAL - 4 stars...I need to remember to come back more often
author: Ed U.

description:
Thai food is always on my radar when I'm in search of anything flavorful and ready to hit the spot. Located in Japantown across the way from the Kimpton Hotel, you wouldn't think a quiet restaurant would exist in such a busy area. Oh and if you're not looking close enough, you can actually miss this restaurant because it's so out of the way and nestled between nail shops and an alteration store. 

I decided to order the Gaeng Keaw Wan, Green Curry with Chicken and was not disappointed. This was really delicious. 

Keep in mind that this restaurant is tiny and doesn't have much seating. Street parking can be challenging especially later in the evening, although there is Japantown Public Car Garage on the other side of the block on Post Street.
author: Ann S.

description:
Located in Japantown on Sutter and Buchanan, this cozy Thai restaurant was the perfect choice for a last minute late night Friday dinner. 

Menu featured all the familiar Thai dishes -- curries, noodles, hot and sour flavors, and your choice of heat, mild, medium or hot.

Favorite dish of the night had to be the pumpkin curry -- smooth and mild with just a hint of sweetness. Also enjoyed the Thai version of an empanada, deep fried pastry puffs stuffed with veggies. 

The chicken larb was just okay and the green curry with tofu could have used a bit more heat but two of our dining mates prefer mild so we kept the heat low.

Friendly service and reasonable prices make this a good value. I'd come back!
author: Sharon H.

description: Have had a chance to come in for lunch, and dinner. Have also had delivery on many occasions. I can attest to all the other rave 5 Star reviews here. Whoever's in the kitchen is doing a great job. Service is also excellent. My favorite order here is chicken larb with Tom yum soup, with a fresh coconut... but everything else I've had is excellent too!
author: Jen H.

description:
Solid thai place in the middle of japan town, this is a really small set up so be sure to reserve a table if you're coming with a large group or prepare for a wait!

We had most of the different curries on our table the last time I was here and I can confidently say that they're all good in their own way/unique and different. Do make sure you read the descriptions since some are more soup/liquid than paste curries, but I thoroughly enjoyed all of them!
author: Andrew T.

description:
This is the best Thai place in SF I've been to. If you come across this place don't pass it up. 

Their food looks exactly like the photos it's amazing
author: Hoda A.

description: I recommend the pad thai and pumpkin curry beef. Super good.
author: Sunil R.

description: This spot was really cute, I came here with a friend and the restaurant was about half filled the entire time. The staff was fairly attentive, but there was a time when my friend made eye contact with a server and they pretended not to notice. The staff was really nice and helpful when we asked for peanut sauce and hot sauce. We got the trout in banana leaf and the pad Thai. The trout was AMAZING- the meat was grilled to perfection and just melted into your mouth. The vegetables it came with were cooked in the same sauce the fish was covered with. We ate this with the hot sauce and it was really good. The hot sauce wasn't too spicy, but added just the right kick to our food. The pad Thai was our safe dish, just in case we didn't like the trout so we had something to fall back on. It was good but my friend ordered peanut sauce to go with it because he didn't think it was peanut-y enough. I thought it was good, but generally prefer milder peanut flavors than him. It came with some bean sprouts and shaved carrots on the side. Both dishes came with lime which we squeezed onto the fish. They also have two Thai beers, one is the Singha which we got and was a good complement to the fish and pad Thai. Would go back, the food was good. Their bathroom is inside the kitchen, so while walking by we noticed the unique and clean kitchen as well. Check it out if you can
author: Kulmeher D.

description: Found this place while searching for Thai in Japan town and glad we stopped in!! Great seating for groups and great chill atmosphere. And the food... so good!! I had the Pad Thai and others in our group had the curries and it all looked so good. Good service, good food and a great vibe - definitely recommend!
author: Tabita P.

description: This place is a treasure. Based in an unassuming block it's like you stepped into Bangkok. The flavors blend together perfectly and the attention to detail is immense: it's authentic in the best possible way. Food wise, the pineapple curry is killer and served in half a pineapple!! Every time I go I discover something new and delicious. Be sure to check opening hours, can be surprising.
author: Zara S.

description:
This was the best Thai food  I had in a long time even my wife who is Thai agreed.
The service was excellent and very friendly. The owner  came out to introduce herself
This is one Thai restaurant you should go when visiting San Francisco.
author: Paul S.

description: Ordered delivery and the food arrived not very warm. I personally didn't care for the noodles. Overall I thought it was ok but I wouldn't consider ordering again.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Probably somewhere between 3 and 3.5 stars for me.  I think the biggest downside here for me was the price - it ended up costing about $26.50/person after tax and tip for 2 people, which is much higher than I expected for the food we got.  

We ordered a soup, the pad see ew, and the evil princess curry.  The soup came out first and it wasn't anything too impressive for me.  I thought that there were too many inedible ingredients inside, and that filtering those things out might have made that experience better.  The pad see ew tasted pretty standard for me, and the evil princess curry was also pretty standard.  I was a bit scared of the spiciness levels, so we opted to get medium spiciness on the curry, but it wasn't very spicy so I'd recommend opting for a hotter option if you love spicy things like me!

Overall, I thought the food was pretty average/OK, but the prices were definitely a bit high for the food quality.  The service was good and the waitress was really nice!  In the end though, I think I would opt for cheaper Thai alternatives next time.
author: Tim L.

description: Delicious food!! Loved the papaya salad because it wasn't spicy! It's hard to find a place that has good non spicy papaya salad. The pad Thai is also sooo good. I will definitely be coming back. It's a small place but we came on a Friday and it wasn't crowded at all.
author: Isabel P.

description: And much better than average Thai restaurant with a delightful host. Their duck is especially good as is the mango sticky rice dessert
author: Jonathan G.

description: Pad kee Mao is fire. BIG BOY portions. Kind of low key, hidden. Staff is v nice. Always satisfied on my Jitlada nights!
author: Kevin W.

description: Went in for lunch and ordered the ginger chicken. The ginger sauce was very refreshing and had a very good ginger flavor. One of the better Thai food places I have food at in a while.
author: Dhruv M.

description: This place is yummy! The food is so fresh and the staff is very friendly. The location is tucked away in Japan Town off a quiet street. It's really a hidden gem. I found this restaurant on Yelp and was initially drawn in by the delicious pictures of food, very impressed by their health score. I will definitely be back!
author: Yvonne S.

description: This was the best Thai delivery I have had in a long time. The delivery arrived before the posted expected delivery time.  The Pad Thai was still fresh and not dry when it got here and had plenty of flavor.  Yellow curry was also very good while it had mostly onions in it I still enjoyed it. Recommended delivery Thai!
author: Meg O.

description: This place is mediocre and the other yelp rating is overrated. Average food and only okay customer services. After we sit down for more than 5 minutes (the place was not busy at all), no server ask for water or drink. After serving other customers who came after us, the waitress final came and asked for order. The signature dish bbq chicken is not tasty at all, over fried and greasy. The pan fry noodle is over cook. 18% tips is auto charged for party of 6. This is a one time place, we will not be back.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Got take-out once. It was quick, good sized portions and the pad thai (only thing I had) was good.

I'd like to go back and try other things.
author: Sylvia B.

description: Pretty good Thai food restaurant. The service was excellent. We were greeted and seated very quickly. The server gave me a wonderful recommendation. She was very happy and easy to talk to. The dish I ordered had very delicious sauces, however the meat was a little tough and hard to chew. That was my only complaint. All together it was a very good meal!
author: Trevor J.

description: I actually order takeout/delivery through the Yelp app for the first time. Ordering was easy and my food arrived quicker than the app indicated. The food was delivered piping hot and everything was fresh and delicious. Overall wonderful experience.
author: Shannon B.

description:
We came here because we were craving Thai (like always) before heading off to Japantown and this was the closest Thai restaurant we Yelped. 

Ambiance: spacious, neat and each table has a real rose flower on it - cute!

Service: relaxing and just great! She even gave us candy afterwards because it was the day before Halloween.

Food: Evil princess curry - I don't know why they called it this but this curry was BOMB. Sweet, coconutty, and so so so yummy! This was my favorite dish here and I highly recommend it.

Pineapple fried rice - I love that dish has raisins and cashew nuts in it. But it didn't stick out to me as amazing.

Pad kee mau - not the best but decent. I like mines a bit sweeter and less oily. 

Overall, great experience here. If I was in the area again, I'd come try out their other dishes + grab another plate of evil princess curry!
author: Cindy M.

description:
Came here for a quick dinner before an event.  The inside was cute and reminded me of a florist shop.  There were tons and tons of really pretty orchids everywhere!

The menu had lots of great dishes to chose from.  It was a hard decision but I asked the waitress what she would pick between the green curry and the special garlic shrimp and she told me the special shrimp so I was an easy sell.

The portion was not very big.  I think there were 5-6 shrimps on a huge bed of cabbage with a few pieces of plain steamed broccoli.  It was almost $20.  The sauce tasted like a cheap Chinese takeout sweet and sour sauce.  

My girlfriend got the green curry which was ok but nothing amazing.  I've actually made curry that tasted better.  

Overall, this meal was pretty meh to me.  I don't think I would go back.  Especially since I've been spoiled with really good Thai food like Kin Khao (a Michelin rated spot!).
author: Kimberly L.

description:
This is a very cute, somewhat intimate + homey environment restaurant close by to Japantown. This place has a wider range of food selection than most thai places I been too. (Like whoa, they offer curry in a pineapple? sweet!) My friend and I got the red curry and pad kee mao to share. For rice they also give you the option of regular rice, or sticky rice. Both dishes were delicious, surprisingly this picky eater here doesn't have one complaint about either dishes LOL If you were to ask me which one I preferred more, I can't because they were both great! They were both rich in flavor, and hearty portions of protein (aka they didn't cheap out on the meat!) Lastly the staff + service here is great, constant water refills and quick + prompt service. 

I would definately reccomend this place to anyone!
author: Jenny N.

description:
It was a letdown after reading such great reviews.

PAD THAI: it had too much of something that made it almost sweet.  When it came out, it looked like it was going to have a slightly funky taste to it because it looked almost pink.  And for me, I don't like when my pad thai is pink.  I like my pad thai to have a more brownish color and have a more savory flavor too.  One thing it did have going for it was that it was full of chicken - a little too much for me, but hey at least it had a lot.

RED CURRY: really flavorful and super coconut-y.  I just wish there was more eggplant in it. I would eat this again for sure, but I'm just not sure I'd be back. Oh and it doesn't come with rice, so you have to pay to order rice with it.

So ultimately the curry was probably 4.5 stars, but the pad thai was just such a let down that I rounded down to two stars. I was really hoping for more.

Bathrooms are upstairs in the back and you need a key that you take from the kitchen.

Street parking - don't block anyone's driveway!
author: Traci H.

description: Ever had food so good you don't want to eat it because then it'll be gone?  This place has that food!  Absolutely delicious.  Ordered delivery and it actually arrived hot.  Never happens.  I don't usually order noodle dishes because they always taste funky.  Not here.  It was so good I saved some to take to work for lunch the next day.  The shrimp veggie fried rolls are better than any Spring Roll ever!  The Evil something curry should be illegal.  That good!  Been eating Thai for over 30 years in quite a few cities.  This place tops them all.  Glad I have found the best Thai in SF!
author: Lynne P.

description:
This is pretty solid Thai food in the midst of Japantown. The space is not very big, but it was not full on a Saturday night even though we were one of two parties of 9 or 10. Which was not a big deal for us anyway, since it did take a bit of time to get all our food ready (but nothing outrageous in terms of waiting). The waitstaff were also reasonably attentive and quite friendly.

I was able to try the pad kee mao and the spicy basil. For the latter we had ordered sliced chicken, although they gave us ground chicken and acknowledged the miscommunication, which was no big deal. Both were very good and decently sized. A lot of vegetables in the pad kee mao, and the noodles had flavor and a nice soft texture. On the bottom was a large leaf of lettuce, which was refreshing.
author: Tony D.

description:
Came here due to the good reviews but not a fan.

Restaurant is super crammed, service is slow to non-existent if you sit at the corner. And this place is apparently filled with kids! I love kids but having them run around in a crammed restaurant. Not everything is family friendly
author: Jesse J.

description:
Super dope amazing curry unbelievable pad Thai super juicy time noodles super dope.

Unbelievably good oh yeah!
author: Jacob K.

description:
It might be odd to come to Japantown for Thai food, but this is the spot to do it if you are in the neighborhood and feeling Thai.

The food here taste solid and they are nicely plated. I was really craving for Thai fried rice, and they said they can ask the kitchen to make it for me even though it's not on the menu. 

I saw a couple moms walking in asking if they can make kids portion and they accommodated the request too.

Overall a good experience. Will come back again.
author: Joseph L.

description:
My list for best Thai food restaurants has been revised again after I came to this place.
It is located just on the north side of Japan Town in SF.
Small, cute restaurant run by an old couple. The wife is the best cook ever!!
Food here is probably one of the best I have ever had!!
Try ordering something else besides Pad Thai. Their food is seriously divine!
Makes me want to go back soon!!
author: Toshie L.

description: Super good Thai food...spicy kick that's just right for me but I'm someone who loves dousing my food with hot sauce and my pizza with red chili flakes (*may be too spicy for some, in which case I'd let them know your preference since they have never asked us). Polite and friendly staff, have only ever dined in. Sticky rice and mango is fantastic and a big portion for the price. Only complaint is that this place is a bit on the pricier end of Thai places in the city..adds up. Worth it for a bit of a splurge on Thai.
author: Lauren M.

description: Owner is very friendly in this neighborhood gem. Found this place by accident and do not live in SF... flavor is excellent... wish more vegetarian options were available but you can't complain about the food
author: Biren S.

description: Ordered 6 different dishes and all were mediocre at best. Oily sauces, watery curries, tough meat. Much better food available in the area, stay away.
author: Dave C.

description: My husband and I we're visiting Japan town again and decided to eat Thai. We found this place. There was only one lady doing everything out front. I wish I took down her name to give her full accolades.  She greeted, seated, took orders, rang up tickets and bust the tables! All with a smile and pleasant attitude!  BRAVO! I had to personally tell her so. We had the Ginger shrimp, chicken satay, pad thai with shrimp and chicken and the pork ribs. Everything was delicious. Going through the kitchen to get to the bathroom was weird,  but otherwise,  very good experience.
author: Roslene W.

description:
Made a reservation for a Saturday night. Cozy spot that's nestled in the corner of Japantown, away from the noise. 

I think this is the first Thai place I've been to where I didn't look at a ten page menu. So take that as you will. We opted for the following...

-thai samosas: goodness, I think I just love traditional samosas so much to ever be sold on thai samosas
-ginger shrimp roll: these are okay, I'd probably not recommend
-evil princess curry: second favorite dish. Has a kick and it's just different enough from red curry for you to appreciate it
-khao soi: favorite dish at the table. Really good, really filling.
-pad talay: good, on the small side.
-coconut rice: is it possible to screw up coconut rice? Whatever, delicious, obviously. 

Despite the lack of people working, the wait staff was extremely friendly. I think that alone bumps up the experience to 4 stars. Food was good, overall, but probably not the best thai food in the city. Definitely would come back for that Northern Thai noodle dish though.
author: Arezou A.

description:
Really good and authentic Thai food! We got the evil princess which was a curry and it tasted amazing. My favorite out of the three dishes that we ordered. 

Next we had pad see ew noodles again amazing and a second favorite. Last but not least we had fried rice which were so so. 

I also got a wine.. #8 on the list and it tasted very watered down. I mean I'm no wine expert but I've had a fair share of Cabernet. 

They close at 9:30 and we arrived at 9:10 thinking they wouldn't let us in but they let us order and other guests arrived even after us and were allowed to be seated as well. 

Great place for take out.
author: Nikita B.

description:
Cute spot in Japantown with really good Thai food. Their pad thai was on point, and their green curry was really good as well. 

Service was attentive without being overbearing. I actually like this place more so than other Thai places (Osha, King of Thai, etc.) and highly recommend.
author: Evelyn C.

description: The #20 was great. Had it spicy with prawns. However the shrimp in sleeping bags appetizer was not great. The flavor of the food is incredible and they can really make it spicy if you ask.
author: Mathew C.

description:
This is an INTIMATE SWEET and absolutely charming restaurant! 

The restaurant owner/head waitress/manager is SO sweet!

Definitely one of my go-to places! I order from them a few times per week and I've been here many times with my boyfriend! We both LOVE it.

My recommendations: the curries  (YUM!), the veggie dishes, and top any with brown rice and a touch of Sricha sauce.

Very healthy and fresh. Not too much oil and flavors are absolute perfection. Love it! 5 stars and a hidden delight here in the bay! 

Happy dining and yum yum
author: Sarah M.

description:
Stopped in here for a quick lunch- glad we did! 

A little gem hidden away on the edge of Japantown- 

A customer there recommended the Pumpkin Curry- which I love but I've pretty much given up ordering in Bay Area Thai  places because it is so often disappointing. I'm glad I listened- it was outstanding. 

The Yam Ma Meung (MANGO SALAD) was incredible. 

Thai Iced Tea- excellent.

The flavors of what we ate here were so perfectly balanced. Thai food, simply done right. Fresh ingredients prepared with care.

This isn't a touristy place, despite its close proximity to Japantown.  I'll be back to try more dishes. We enjoyed the delicious  food and the wonderful welcoming helpful service.
author: Susan B.

description:
I randomly stumble across Thai restaurants when I need a snack. 

Sunday evening- decent amount of people.

The layout is pretty unique but it works well. The Christmas balls dangling on the ceiling are cool.

Service- it was okay. Not the best nor the worst.

Food- I Ordered "Wrap me Up" for $10, it's on the Chef special menu. It is 6 large spinach leaves, each topped with toasted coconut, mine had like 2 teeny cubes of the following: (per leaf) red onion (supposed to be shallots), carrot, ginger, and 1/3 of a shrimp. It was served with a tamarind sauce.

Pretty presentation. Good mix of flavors but it wasn't satisfying. I was sad with the teeny amount of shrimp. It was a very sweet dish, I wish there was a little more "oomph" to it.

Ps- for the bathrooms you have to go all the way back, get a key & go through the kitchen.

Maybe someday I'll stumble across this place again and try an entree.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Fantastic Thai cuisine! The restaurant was surprisingly pretty empty on a weekend evening. Service was quick and attentive.

We ordered the basil stuffed eggplant ($10). This was such a unique delicious appetizer. You could really taste the strong basil flavor in the sauce. We loved it!

For an entree got the pad kee mao ($11) with beef. The flavors were so savory and again you could really taste the basil which was great! The flat thick noodles were cooked so well. It's a large serving size and you could share this dish alone with another person and be full. The other entree we got was the yellow curry ($11) with chicken. Wow this was the highlight of the meal for me. A bit spicy but perfectly flavored and hit the spot. Loved how soft the potatoes were. Unfortunately it doesn't come with rice so we ordered a bowl for an extra $2.
author: Linda X.

description:
The ginger shrimp rolls are incredible.  I could eat 50 of them!

Prices are higher than your typical thai joint, but the quality is noticeable and worth the trade off.  I rarely order from anywhere else now. 

Delivery is prompt too!
author: Bobby L.

description: This charmingly intimate restaurant is a true delight just around the corner from the Buchanan hotel. Our server was a gracious host and we enjoyed a refreshing bottle of Sauvignon Blanc. Pad Thai noodles with chicken is my go to Thai dish, but my companion encouraged me to be adventurous - we're on vacation after all. We ordered the Grilled Salmon with vegetables and the Trout in Banana Leaf. Both were spectacularly delicious. I usually stay near the Financial District, but Jitlada is definitely worth the cab ride if you don't live nearby. Bravo.
author: Ralph C.

description:
Ordered Garlic Prawns, tom yum, somtum, jungle curry and pad keemao.

Tom Yum: Hit the spot. Sour and salty. My mouth water just thinking of it.

Garlic Prawns: $18.95. Eeeeer, it's delish but for that price, we should get more than 6 shrimp. Yes, should not be promoted as prawn at all. 

Som Tum: Meh.... usually som tom is spicy, fiah saucy with fragrant lime and cilantro. Their dish was on the sweet side. What's unusual though, they have shrimp in it.

Jungle Curry: My husband like it. I'm not that crazy. Maybe I did not read the menu correctly, but I though curry comes with coconut milk. 

Pad Kee Mao: We had chicken pad kee mao. It was yummy. You get that smokey charred taste of soy sauce in hot wok. 

Overall this is an okay establishment. Nothing wow us. Will not come back anytime soon.
author: Merry K.

description: Absolutely LOVE this spot! My go-to is the Jungle Curry because it doesn't have coconut milk and has an insanely flavorful broth. The curries here are loaded with veggies and the whole menu offers more interesting dishes than I have seen at other Thai restaurants.
author: Danielle L.

description: Nice place and they were able to accommodate my dietary needs of a vegan dish with no oil and no salt in it. What resulted was a savory sautéed vegetable bowl with brown rice with some lemon juice on the side. Was very tasty. The price is definitely much higher than what I thought is apt for that dish. So hard to visit such places unless you must.
author: Ram A.

description: Decent Thai food, but definitely had better in the city. Tried the pad thai, noticed portions were a bit on the smaller side.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
This Thai place is definitely a family owned restaurant located right outside of Japantown. It seats about 30 people so if you have a larger party, I recommend making a reservation.

Overall the food was really tasty. We tried the pad kee mow, evil princess curry, and the spicy basil. Each dish was really flavorful and delicious, the only thing to note is that the portions are SMALL. These are not family style and not meant to be shared!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Had the red curry with beef. It was very tasty. I picked hot but I like it a bit hotter normally. Should have chosen very hot.
author: Conor M.

description: We only got a couple soups and the ginger shrimp spring rolls but it was excellent! Nicely flavored, spicy and not too sweet.
author: Nicolle P.

description:
Excellent lunch here. We both had the mango salad and it was delicious- lots of great ingredients with a perfectly balanced dressing. Washed down with their regular water to which they have added some citrus. I also got red curry with just vegetable with red rice. The curry sauce was so good I spooned up every last drop. 

Service was pleasant and the atmosphere was nice. 

Only drawback is bathroom isn't accessible if you can't walk four or five stairs. .
author: Marco M.

description:
Absolutely amazing. We had Pork Pumpkin Curry and Chicken Pad Thai. The food was absolutely amazing. The sticky rice was divine. The Pork Pumpkin Curry was fantastic, and the Chicken Pad Thai was divine. I highly recommend this restaurant. 

Note: if you order something hot (spicy), it's very, very spicy. Delicious, but just something to note.
author: Erin D.

description:
Home style Thai made literally by a single cook. Don't ever expect to receive your food at the same time. And if there are a bunch of people,  then just forget it. 

Spicy is never spicy enough and they don't have a spice rack.  When you ask, they will give you hot sauce or red pepper depending on how they translate your request and never actually ask which one you want.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Great. Pad Thai was better than average. Jungle curry I ordered medium and it was so hot I couldn't eat it, and I'm not a chilli wimp.
author: Peaches P.

description: Love this place. Khao soi is the bomb. The service is great and friendly. The cook in the back will come out to greet the customers. They have been in business for a long time.  It's a rare find in this city full of pretentious and not authentic Thai restaurants
author: Lan P.

description: Wish I could give this place a 3.5. Good flavors overall but the curries are a bit too sweet for me.
author: Dustin H.

description: most food in jtown makes me wana kill myself but this is a neat little place away from all that chaotic weeby energy. authentic food with really friendly employees. one of the servers had some kinda siousxie and the banshee vibe goin on and i loved it so much. she was so helpful and u can tell she really knows her shit bc the recommendations she gave my friend and i were the bomb dot com.
author: Tiffany X.

description:
Fantastic delivery!  Timely and very nice!  Prices are reasonable at ~$10 a dish.

Evil Princess Curry: red coconut curry with cabbage, basil, and choice of meat, $9.95 (extra $2 for shrimp).  You choose the level of spiciness--I like medium, which is still spicy but not runny nose spicy.  Boyfriend and I agree that this just might be the best Thai curry we've ever had.  Highly recommended!

Mango w/black sticky rice: it's actually purple rice, and the mango is sliced very thinly to have perfect bite-sized portions along with the rice, $5.50.  Love the relatively unique rice, which makes it not taste quite as sweet as other places, and lends to varying textures in each bite.  It's also served on a banana leaf (even delivery), which is a nice touch.

Pad ka prow: stir fried bell peppers, onions, basil, and green beans with choice of meat (I recommend ground chicken), $9.95.  Flavorful, spicy (again I like medium), with a slightly sweet taste which I love in savory food.  Decent sized portion too.  Would get again!
author: Vanessa O.

description:
My relationship with Jitlada has been an emotional roller coaster.

It started with a complaint to a coworker that I haven't been able to find what I consider to be authentic Thai food in SF. (After spending a few weeks backpacking there I have become a totally self-righteous expert on authentic Thai food so this gives me great authority to judge this stuff ok.) My coworker said I have to try Jitlada. "It's the best." She proclaimed.

I raced over after work and selected a few dishes to go: Khao Soi, stuff eggplant, and papaya salad. While waiting for my food I was chatting with the owner, she was super nice and smiled patiently as I practiced the four Thai words I know. She was a trooper for what must have been complete cultural butchery on my part.

I asked for the papaya salad to be "Thai spicy", AKA try to kill me spicy. 

Upon arrival at home and after excitedly opening the bag of food a few things occurred:

1. The stuffed eggplant tasted great, maybe a bit small but oh well.

2. The papaya salad had what I'd consider to be a mild amount of spice. (Mind you I'm not one of those crazy people who brush their teeth with ghost peppers, I just like a kick to my papaya salad.) Other than that, quite good.

3. This one was the red flag: they used linguine pasta noodles in the Khao Soi. When I saw this my heart sank. All my other nit-picky complaints were minor, but this was just completely weird to me. I've never seen this and it is a source of total confusion. Did they run out of the traditional and universally common flat egg noodles? Are pasta noodles cheaper? Is the world about to end? I might never know.

I'll probably come back to try some more dishes, but my hunt for Thai food continues.
author: Ben A.

description:
3.5 stars. Pretty solid food but can't distinguish it from many thai places in the city.

Tom kha gai soup w ith coconut milk: wish that they haf a better ingredient to liquid ratio but taste of the soup was good.

Evil princess curry with chicken: it was so so. Wasn't blown away especially given how many people recommended it. I prefer my curries to be hearty and has quite a bit of vegetables and chicken, and this one just didn't meet the expectation. The napa cabbage and spinach shrank quite a bit in the curry soup - not sure if they are the best ingredients to put inside a curry.

Sauteed eggplant with tofu: liked the eggplant - the tofu was mediocre.

Given how many restaurants there are in SF, I probably won't be back here. Thai basil downtown is much better.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Found this while searching for a dinner spot before a evening movie at Kabuki.

My fiancee and i haven't varied too far off the beaten path of their menu but we've had various curries (all delicious), the Pad Kee Mao is a must and the service is extremely quick. 

This has quickly become a go to spot for us when we are in the area, and our only tripe is that they don't deliver to our neighborhood. Regardless, 5 stars!
author: Matthias K.

description: Exquisite thai cuisine. I went with a group o friends and the place was perfect. Not crowded at all. And the food was delicious!
author: Maureen B.

description: A friend pointed us to Jitlada Thai and it was not the BEST Thai I've ever had, but also far from the worst. The flavors were good, but the portions were on the smaller side. I got the yellow curry with chicken and the potatoes were perfectly cooked, but there was not much chicken in the dish. My husband got the khao soi with chicken and again, the flavors were delicious, but I'm fairly certain they used linguine noodles, which was ... unexpected. We were also the only patrons in the restaurant our entire time there, and we were there on a Friday or Saturday night at 7PM!
author: Hillary M.

description:
There's a restaurant in LA with the same name and I've always thought that restaurant was overrated. So when my friend suggested Jitlada before our movie at Sundance Kabuki Theater, negative thoughts came to mind and I was initially hesitant.

I was pleasantly surprised by the experience. I love that you can just walk right in. I'm so tired of waiting in never-ending lines or making reservations weeks in advance just to eat in this city.

We ordered the Crying Tiger salad, Khao Soi noodles, and Red Curry. The flavors are definitely toned down for the American palate (unlike the Thai places in Thai Town LA) but still delicious. The Crying Tiger could've used a bit more of a kick. I thought it was odd that the noodles in the Khao Soi were linguine but I suppose it tasted alright. The red curry had a disproportionate amount of  veggies compared to meat but my friend enjoyed it, nonetheless. With 1 thai iced tea and 1 brown rice, total damage with tax and tip was about $45.

I guess it's cheaper than the incredibly overpriced Osha and grading on a curve, I rate it 4 stars.
author: Yi Z.

description: Intimate, cute little place, awesome food.  Simple as that.  I would definitely pay them another visit if I happened to be in the area.
author: Mallory C.

description:
Amazing food tastes like it's been homemade in an actual Thai kitchen. 

Great vegetarian options for those who are looking for a escape from the basic noodle and veggies dish. 

The place has a very homey atmosphere as well
author: Sandhya S.

description: Low key....efficient service....quiet ambience....DELICIOUS FOOD!  I highly recommend Jitlada for those who love Thai cuisine.  I know this sounds basic, but order the Yellow Chicken Curry -- the best I have ever had.  Don't get me started on the short ribs.  Truly exceptional.
author: Mitch N.

description:
This was my go to Thai spot in the city as you can read my precious review.. Until something has changed. I don't know what it is but it's changed. 

The flavors became less exciting and much more bland although it may be healthier but I'm not ordering here to have less sodium I'm ordering here on my chest days. 

The quality of the dishes have definitely fell short and is not up to par and I'm very sad about it. Come back!!
author: Sarah K.

description:
This place was fantastic. Just off the main square by the Peace Pagoda in Japan town, Jitlada is set back from traffic in a quiet little storefront. The inside is clean and nicely furnished with an eye for comfort- no sardine seating here!

The food struck that sweet spot between savory and spicy thanks to the waitress allowing us to customize our spiciness level. Tom Kha Gai soup often ends up too sour or too watery, but Jitlada gets it just right with the coconut milk to lemongrass ratio, rich and full of mushrooms and chicken. The curries are flavorful and complex, and the seafood fresh. The only pitfall is the overall sweetness of the sauces. American palates tend to favor sweeter dishes than I like, so it's probably just fine for the average fan of Thai food.

Overall, the prices were reasonable for San Francisco, and the service was just fine, ten minutes for apps and ten more for entrees. The waitstaff was kind and attentive about drinks and additional service. I'll definitely be back. 

Mom-n-Pop establishments move at an easy pace, so if you are crunched for time or are a super control freak, maybe hit McDonalds or something instead of taking it out on the waitstaff, eh?
author: Emily H.

description:
Disclaimer: I live so close to this place that Yelp is suggesting that I check-in even though I'm sitting at home, so this review may be biased by the fact that it is so ridiculously convenient.

But still I think my opinion is valid when I say that this is a really solid Thai place: it serves delicious and reliable food and is (somehow) never crowded. And I went to school in a city with pretty great Thai food, so I have pretty high standards.

I recommend getting a curry with rice, as all of the curries I've had have been delicious. Of all the curries I've tried, green curry is my favorite. It's really flavorful and thick with a nice hint of coconut. If spicy food is your thing, get the Evil Princess Curry, which is spicy and savory. It's unlike any other curry I've tried so far. The Red Curry is also delicious, though a bit on the salty side. I have yet to try the noodles, but my friends have had good things to say about the Pad Thai and Pad See Ew (I think the Pad See Ew might go by a different name, though). Portions are very generous and prices are quite reasonable.

Service is friendly and attentive, and the atmosphere is calm and cozy (like the rest of Japantown, except when there's ramen/JPop festivals). If you're in the area and looking for something other than ramen and Korean food, walk up Buchanan and visit this unassuming restaurant with great Thai food.
author: Brittany C.

description:
Came here for dinner last night with my husband, looking to cure our post-vacation Blues. We just got back from a two week vacation in Thailand, where we developed a severe addiction to khao soi and panang curry. This place did not disappoint! While the khao soi wasn't exactly like chiang mai's version, it was tasty and the panang curry was great. 

Crowd-wise, it was moderately busy for an early Friday night dinner. No reservations needed. 

Also, my Thailand loving heart melted when I heard the staff greet one of their regulars with a friendly "sawasdee ka" (Thai for "hello").

We will definitely be back!
author: Kelly L.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco. I always come here when i crave Thai food :) The owners are so nice they always make me feel like home.
author: Avoca D.

description:
Ordered from postmates and they charged me $8 for white rice when I requested it off the menu.  Such an obnoxious price gouge.  Don't give dishonest people money.

For comparison my main course was $10.
author: Alex W.

description: This is my favorite Thai takeout in the city.  The service is excellent, always very speedy, and the staff is cheerful and kind.  Highly recommend the evil princess and the northern Thailand dish.
author: Laura S.

description:
This place is authentic, delicious and a hidden gem! I came here with friends on a Saturday night and was surprised to find that there was no wait at all. I recommend getting the green curry, mango salad and Evil Princess curry.

The curries are creamy and rich. Rice doesn't come with the dishes so you'd need to order that separately.
author: Lillian C.

description: Was looking for a place that wasn't too crowded during the Cherry blossom festival and I arrived at Jitlada, service right from the start was great. We were greeted by a nice gentleman and seated. Shortly after he took our orders and before I knew it the Chef Pai herself delivered her amazing dishes. My sister ordered the crying tiger salad and I had satay chicken. Both dishes were delicious and ingredients were truly fresh, I would recommend anyone this place for their great customer service and food! Will be back most definitely!!
author: Jose M.

description: Absolutely one of my FAVORITE places with delicious food and incredibly nice owner! I always have a great conversation with the woman who runs the place. And the food! Absolutely delish. I recommend coming with an empty stomach.
author: Sal F.

description:
My girlfriend and I met up with some friends for dinner before our turn at the Mysterious Room, and Jitlada was chosen at the spot.  There was plenty of parking in Japantown and we arrived right on time for our reservation.

We started off with their mango salad and tom kha chicken soup.  The table really enjoyed the mango salad, though I though the onions could have been cut much smaller for my taste and I found the chicken to be kind of tough.  The special BBQ chicken was delicious, and was served with sticky rice.  It was probably my favorite dish of the evening.  The pumpkin curry was a bit sweet and there wasn't enough of the yummy pad se-eiw.  Overall, a solid meal with more highs than lows.

Service was friendly, but lost attentiveness at points in the meal.  The bathroom is located behind the restaurant so you have to pass through the kitchen and out the back door in order to reach it.  Besides that, I enjoyed the food and would definitely order that chicken again.  Give it a try!

Food: 7/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: My fave Thai place in town.  Family run,  will cook meals custom if you have a favorite.
author: Molly C.

description: Very nice and clean local Thai restaurant. The food is excellent including a wide selection of wine by the glass. Highly recommended..
author: David S.

description:
I came here with a group of 10 on a Saturday evening around 7pm and most of the seats were available. 

I ordered the Khao Soi and my girlfriend ordered the Pad Ka Praw, both dishes we tried in Thailand and ended up loving. 

Khao Soi  - northern thailand dish.
This was pretty good, but not as good as the one I had in Thailand. It's a really unique dish and I'd recommend trying it. 
Pad Ka Prow - It had lots of flavor and I liked this dish too.
author: Edward W.

description:
Top dishes:
Trout in banana leaf
Pumpkin curry with tofu - tofu soaks up the flavor well

Skip next time:
Evil princess - review highlight, unique dish, but I like many of the other great dishes better
author: Mike G.

description:
I'm very thankful to have the foresight of reserving a place to eat in case the Ramen Street Festival failed my friends and I. Given the long lines and major crowds, we never got our ramen and were getting to the point of "hangry." We need food asap! 

I called a few hours beforehand to secure a spot for an early dinner. We unexpectedly added a couple more people to our party and they were able to squeeze the 10 of us in with no problem by putting together two small tables. Upon arrival, ramen-less groups of people were clamoring to get into all the restaurants within proximity of Japantown and we were worried our spot would be forfeited. They still accommodated my party even though we were a few minutes late.

We were still hankering after NOODLES and got different variations of pad thai, pad see ew, pad kee mao, etc. and everyone was very satisfied with their dishes. The CURRIES were also tasty, but the Evil Princess could be spicier. For all VEGETARIAN eaters, pretty much every dish can be made meat-less if you request it. They also look out for VEGANS by asking if you want egg to be included in your dishes.

Our waitress was attentive and kept our water glasses filled up during our entire meal. Even though we were a large group, our food and drinks came out in a timely manner.

Given the decent price and large portions, Jitlada was a saving grace for me this past weekend.
author: Bonnie Z.

description: I had the chicken sausage soup which had vermicelli noodles and egg drop. It's a light and healthy alternative to an entree when eaten with a bowl of white rice. My boyfriend got a pad kee mow which was fine. I was a bit confused that rice doesn't come with entrees such as curry. But they are options as a side, along with brown rice, coconut sticky rice, and peanut sauce (why??). I liked the atmosphere, fairly fancy decor and normal (not shady) customers. I'd come here again to try the black sticky rice with mango, and some type of curry next time when I'm really hungry.
author: Alice S.

description:
I really enjoyed my togo order.  Stuffed Eggplant app, Green Curry Chicken main.  The eggplant app far exceeded expectations.  Green Curry was very good;  I ordered hot, should've gone xtra hot.

Used EAT24 to place/pay for order.  Worked great!
author: Zach N.

description: Whenever we're in Japantown we come to Jitlada. We love Thai food and this is the best I've had so far.
author: Stephen G.

description:
Found this place on Yelp and decided to check it out while visiting SF with my boyfriend, his sister, and his mom. We all loved the place!! I was half expecting a big restaurant, but it turned out to be this cute, little place! I loved the ambiance! The decor is really elegant. 

The service wasn't so great when we arrived. We were kind of in a rush, so after a few minutes of not being waited on, we seated ourselves. There were basically 4 people that work in the restaurant, but what was really cool was that the chef comes out to talk to everyone about the food. The waitress was also very nice and paid attention to us a lot, so that made up for the bad arrival! 

The food is incredible!! We ordered pad Thai, pad talay, and their duck special. Everything was delicious!!! I am a pad Thai LOVER, and I can tell you, that is got to be one of the BEST pad Thais I have ever tasted!! All the dishes are a little pricey, but maybe it's just because it's in SF (I'm from Sac). But, I'll tell you, it's totally worth every penny! I do wish the dishes were a teensy bit bigger since the 4 of us were sharing dishes, however, if you were just eating by yourself, the portions are perfect!

BOTTOM LINE: I totally recommend and will DEFINITELY come back whenever I'm in the Bay Area again!
author: Xaviera L.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant. Love the red curry dish and pad kee mao with the coconut sticky rice. Such friendly people work here too. Black sticky rice for dessert is great. You should try it.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Sunday around 7pm, and the restaurant was surprisingly pretty empty. I ordered the pumpkin curry with prawns with a side of brown rice. The prawns were overcooked, and I wish there was a variety of vegetables besides just kabocha, but the flavor of the curry and the large pieces of kabocha were super satisfying. It was a large enough portion that I ended up not really eating my rice, so you can easily share a curry dish, a bowl of rice, and an appetizer!

One thing that I didn't like was that there was a delay of around 10-15 minutes from when the first person got their entree to the last. The timing could definitely be better. Other than that, service was friendly and decently attentive.
author: Abby S.

description: My friends and I attended the ramen festival in japan town and were quite disappointed hearing that it was a 4 hour wait for ramen. We stumbled on to this lil jewel of a place and were the last people seated at 3:30. I had the Evil Princess, red Thai curry with coconut milk as well as a bowl of brown rice. Absolutely delicious.
author: Frank R.

description:
Highlights:
1.  Very friendly service
2.  Nice ambiance
3.  Solid food.  I tried the:  curry puffs (4/5), pad see ew (4/5), and pad ka prow with minced chicken (4.5/5).

Negatives:
1.  Price is a bit too high.  $60 with tax and tip for 2 people.  We ate the above mentioned food and 3 beers (Singha).  Should have been about $20 cheaper.
author: Paul W.

description:
Came here after reading that one of our favorite Thai food places had a terrible health score. This one had a good score and the reviews were pretty fair. This place blew my wife and me away. The location was tucked away near Japan town in a very charming neighborhood, you'd almost never notice it. Inside reminded me of a coffee shop, the tables were well organized (not too cramped). Our service was great, we didn't need a reservation and were immediately seated on a Friday around 6:30. The restaurant was a little more than half full.

We ordered the shrimp in sleeping bags, Tom ka soup to share both as appetizers. For our mains we ordered combination fried rice and the house noodles with shrimp. This was so much food; it's family style apparently, never a bad thing. For dessert we ordered the sticky rice.

Here's the breakdown:

Shrimp in sleeping bags - excellent crispy, good flavor; although, a little more shrimpy than I normally like. Sauce was perfectly sweet and spicy.
Tom ka - perfect consistency, nice balance of coconut milk and water, not too creamy. Was a bit salty but still delicious.
House noodle (added baby corn) - wow
Fried rice w/ shrimp and chicken - best fried rice ever, wow
Mango sticky rice - more wow


The end.
author: James M.

description:
Amazing!
Veggie spring rolls were packet full and nicely crispy. Ordered Sam Da Hai with chicken. Very good. Fresh crispy vegetables, tender chicken, and mouth popping flavors of ginger and Thai flavor.
author: E G.

description: I love this place!  The owner is amazing,  and the KHAO SOI is so good you crave it!   I might just have to drive to sf tomorrow to get some!
author: Karen F.

description: Yummy Thai. Love the mieng kum and evil princess dishes and the waitress is super sweet.
author: Myra Y.

description:
Nice little restaurant tucked away in Japantown.  It has a very quiet atmosphere (no background music playing while you eat). 

I ordered the Pad Kee Mao with chicken and it was good.  Beware though, it is spicy!!  I also shared the fried papaya appetizer with friends.  That was good too but it's a little plain if you don't put some of the sweet & sour sauce that accompanies the dish.
author: Francesca L.

description:
Really really good Thai food. 
Went with the Evil Princess with chicken. 
Also the trout. Both were good and flavorful. 
The only thing I would suggest is to cut back on the sweet.
author: Geordie E.

description:
Ambience is super nice and food is quite good. I'm not really buying their special menu thingy. However, we got 3 dishes and they were all very tasty

Tom yum: pretty standard dish. Portion is pretty big and everything tastes fresh.

We also ordered a noodle dish that was the first one in the menu which I forgot the name. It has coconut based sauce.

Service was quite slow so be prepared for that
author: Ruxin H.

description:
I was all set to give this place 4 stars; going by the food alone, I still would. On our initial visit, a friend and I conversed with our server and by chance segued into asking if the restaurant had a particular traditional Thai ingredient. We described it and showed her photos of it. She said they had it but that one of the workers had already taken the rest of it home that day. She and we decided it would be best for us to call ahead next time to check before coming in to try it.

The next week, I called about the item. The person who answered initially didn't understand my English (not a problem). I elaborated on my inquiry, at which point she said they don't [ever] have it and began laughing right before hanging up. It's not like I called to ask if their refrigerator was running or if I could talk to I. P. Freely.

Some friends and I happened to be in Japantown later that day. The one who accompanied me on my first Jitlada visit walked over to ask in person, just in case the phone conversation had been a language barrier thing. Well, she asked and was subsequently laughed / argued out of the restaurant with, from what she told me, all the patrons watching.

From my Thai friends and the Thai crew I used to run with, my impression of Thai culture is that it's looser, more relaxed than that of America. Yet I don't see openly laughing at - not with - someone and in this manner driving them out of a place as being part of any culture's joviality. Maybe I just don't know.

Again, we like the menu, and we want to explore it more. We even don't mind the moths that make evening cameos around the table. Yet I'm not sure when or if my friend would be up for going back after her experience. I think you should still eat here, so long as you don't try to go off-menu. Or if you do ask about other items, bring one of your Thai friends to helm the conversation in your stead.
author: Dan B.

description:
I was visiting Japantown and wasn't feeling any of the eatery establishments there so I looked to my trusty Yelp app. Yay! It was great discovering this place. It was slightly empty, but that was probably because everyone was eating at the Nihonmachi fair 2 blocks down. 

Ordered basil stuffed eggplant and pumpkin curry. YUM! We were a little scared after seeing the eggplant come out. It looked questionable. The green sauce looked really funky, but SO TASTY! It was a nice surprise and we were happy with our choice. The flavor was just amazing. Really got me in the mood to eat. The curry was alright. It could've used more Thai flavor. The pumpkin was a little too mushy, but still good. 

I don't like having to pay for rice. I feel like it should come with the entree.
author: Cindy K.

description:
Good food, no wait. The pumpkin curry is amazing but it is really small portions and somewhat expensive for the size. The pad see ew isnt great.

Definitely not the best thai I've had, but decent if you live in the area.
author: Amanda C.

description: Super cute place! I had the pad kee mao and my boyfriend had the pad thai. Everything was AMAZING! If you want great Thai food and great service, this is the place you've been looking for.
author: Karina S.

description: First timer here took my girlfriend here for Valentine's Day dinner, food was good but service wise needed much improvement. Service was slow had to be reminded of water and more rice. Thought that food was way too overpriced for dinner. After I paid for dinner left a $2 tip and the waitress said to me "usually our customers leave a 15% tip" I was like ok that's all I have, REALLY?! Then she goes on asking where are you from? I was like I'm from SoCal. "Do they tip where you're from? Was the service not good? Left me speechless. Never will I good back nor recommend anyone to go to this place.
author: David V.

description:
Always exceptional food and great service! 

Highly recommend the Pad See Ew and Ginger Prawn rolls.
author: Kat M.

description: Charming restaurant that provided everything I look for while dining out. Wonderful food, friendly service and all at a good price.
author: John C.

description:
The red and green curries are fantastic. Just the right amount of food, level of spiciness, and meat/veggie balance. 

The owner Pei (sp?) is such a sweet lady!
author: Kevin M.

description: The owner is such a nice person! We have been in a couple of times about 5 years apart. It is healthy, delicious food with great flavors. Spicy is very spicy! We enjoyed both meals.
author: Mary W.

description:
Came on a Friday evening, didn't have to wait for a table but the wait for food was extremely long. Ordered the stuffed eggplant as an appetizer which was very good, though took 30 minutes to arrive.  We had 3 entrees which all arrived at separate times. The third plate of Pad Thai didn't come until after the rest of us finished eating.

Overall the food was pretty good though portions, as others have mentioned, were dinky.  Price was not right.
author: James H.

description:
3.5 stars 

I had such high hopes for this place. It seemed to be the saving grace to the dining hell hole that is Japantown and it helps my grandmother lives around the street corner. Came here for lunch with her and my cousin. 

We ordered the mango prawn salad, pumpkin curry, brown rice, and some tofu lunch bento. The salad was good but the portion was super small. How hard is it to add some more lettuce?! The pumpkin curry was solid and the lunch bento was seemingly a good deal.

While all the food was good, my biggest gripe about this place is the service. The waitress was a total bitch and everything took FOREVER to come out. When we were seated we were handed a set of menus, a couple minutes later we got a second set, then a couple more minutes later we got a third set. WTF?! It took ages just to get some glasses of water and it was impossible to get the waitresses attention. The bathroom is in the way back where you have to walk past the kitchen into some weird room and they seriously have like 8 people working in the kitchen. Why the hell did the food take so long to come out then?! Ridiculous.
author: Tiffany V.

description: The green curry, pad kee mao and prik khing are excellent.  Every thing else is good too.
author: Andrew F.

description: Great food. Service was terribly slow. Not that busy but everything seemed to move extremely slowly. It was painful.
author: Kevin G.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I have attempted to eat at every Thai restaurant in Los Angeles, and ever since I moved to San Francisco, I've begun a similar venture.

Thus far, Jitlada has absolutely pummeled the competition in regards to being the most delicious Thai food I've had in the Bay Area to date. 

Everything was fresh. It looked so appetizing that you'd want to eat everything, including the garnish on the plate. I ordered the Pad Thai, as well as the Pumpkin Curry with Chicken. Both were utterly fantastic. The flavors were perfectly balanced, a level amount of sweetness, and an earthy spiciness that was so pleasant. I'm dying just thinking about it. I want more right now.

Go see for yourself. These two star reviews are crazy. I'm keeping right on my Thai food quest in the Bay, but I can tell you right now: Jitlada will always be one of my favourites.
author: Lauren A.

description: The food was good, nice ambiance and good service.  Tried the eggplant appetizer and it was delicious.  Tom khan was not spicy enough but pretty tasty.  I would come back.
author: Cari N.

description:
really liked this place!
I had lunch box with chicken, sticky rice and veges.
reasonable price and quiet cozy place.
author: Kaori M.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place out for a while so I dragged a friend here and ate for a bit.

The atmosphere is cozy yet fancy. Quiet yet not completely silent. It's definitely better suited for intimate couples/groups. 

The service was nice and attentive. They were polite, friendly, and they made sure we were satisfied with everything.

We ordered Thai iced tea, wrap me ups, and chicken curry puffs. 

The Thai tea was better than most Thai teas I've had in other places yet it wasn't the very best I've ever had. None the less, I was pretty happy with it. Especially because they didn't overdo it on the ice.  

The wrap me ups were good although messy to eat because everything kept slipping out. It was to be expected. There was definitely a ton of coconut but the fillings they put in the wraps are more generous compared to another Thai place I've been to. 

The curry puffs were very good although quite hot when you first get them. The curry puffs reminded me of little empanadas but curry filled. They were by far my favorite.

What's difficult about this place is finding an item on the menu that doesn't have any form of nuts in it. This is to be expected of Thai food, but I'm just putting that out there. 

I liked this place enough but I didn't love it. I do want to try an entree sometime so I plan on coming back.
author: Sofia R.

description: This place makes really great Thai fried rice!  I love it spicy and had requested it extra spicy and they made it just the way I like it!  Thanks Jitlada Thai!!!  I especially love your house chili fish sauce.  Will check out the other menus next time.  Will definitely return and recommend to others!
author: Harry C.

description:
Been here a few times over the past year. In the past went in around 2pm-ish if I recall correctly, and being either the only table, or one of two tables at most, the service was okay.

Today went closer to noon and there were around 5 parties seated. There was only a single waitress, taking her time walking around to each table, and not refilling our water enough. The kitchen is also really slow. Based on the other reviews it seems there's only a single cook.

The curry puff appetizer is good. The green curry was too salty. Didn't really enjoy the barbecue chicken that the waitress recommended.

At the end, no signs posted, the waitress said the credit card machine was broken and asked us to pay cash. She even did a whole song-and-dance, even pulling the age card, saying doing the manual credit card imprinting was "very hard" for her, and did an arm motion to show how strenuous it was to operate the device (despite being able to carry around several heavy dishes at once...). That plus the really slow service guaranteed we would pay cash instead of waiting for the card imprinting -- all the while she watched over my shoulder to make sure I was putting down enough of a tip.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Clean restaurant and courteous service. I shared:

- Crying Tiger (Beef Salad): tastes just like larb salad but with beef. i love the flavors of these salads especially that lime juice. 
- Evil Princess Curry with Chicken: my friend and I didn't specify what heat level we wanted so i'm sure the dish was made mild. it was more of a sweet curry vs. spicy but still very tasty. the dish was a bit skimpy on the chicken though. 
- Roti with Coconut Ice Cream: definitely a sweet, warm treat but the roti was a bit greasy for me. 

On another note, the restaurant could get awkwardly quiet when peoples voices aren't filling the restaurant. I think some music might help.
author: Maya S.

description: Very homey, the nicest and most polite staff. Food was alright, not the tastiest Thai place I've ever had, although I'm sure they're fairly authentic. The three of us ordered two curry dishes and one stir fry, was a bit salty and not enough rice to finish with it. Price was also a bit high, I think our total came to nearly $50 with only three normal sized dishes.
author: Joy H.

description: Food is great. The Pad See Ew is the bomb. Chicken eggplant is excellent. The soft-shell crab is so so and overpriced. Overall everything is very good.
author: Twee W.

description: This is the best Thai in the area. It's not the typical junky Thai fare (I'm looking at you My Ivy & Osha)... the quality is significantly better than you're probably used to. My recent visit was a happy one, and if my memory serves, they seem to have updated the interior (it really needed a makeover). Their whole fish was awesome and service was great.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Sweet mom and pop style shop. It's a smaller place but a lot of care went into the food that we ordered. I've been here for both lunch and dinner and both times it was phenomenal. 

So to give you perspective, I am definitely not a thai food expert. I'm use to what I can find around San Jose which is nothing to write home about. So for me, this place is off the charts awesome. 

I'm a big fan of anything red curry that they make. At lunch, they do have bento box style specials where you can try a little bit of a everything (appetizer, salad, rice, entree). Normally the dishes here are more family size servings, especially for dinner. We had fun ordering a bunch of different things and sharing. 

My favorite part of this restaurant is that you can smell the food cooking from the street and it seduces you in through the front door. The atmosphere is cozy, clean and friendly. It's definitely really convenient if you are near the medical center for business, although it is a little bit of a walk but worth it.
author: Tanja F.

description:
Jitlada surprised me. With its big windows and white interior, the place looked more like a café in Hayes Valley than a Thai restaurant in Japantown. 

Small place with tables mostly for 2 or 4 people. The atmosphere is intimate enough for couples and dates, but also casual at the same time for friends and coworkers.  

Service was friendly and attentive. Chef Pai, the owner and head chef, came out and chatted with every table when she was not busy in the kitchen.

Thai Curry Puffs (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DhxBcPJr1igtHNqDyvJ_lA?select=AUUTD3RjAEYtok_POTBQ1A): Compliments of the chef. She's working to have these curry puffs on the regular menu and wanted our opinion. The pastry shell was crispy and the mixture of potato, carrot and onion mashed together was fantastic. The puffs alone were delicious already, but the sauce made them amazing! Sweet and tangy sauce with assorted vegetables and peanuts! Thanks Chef Pai!

Evil Princess Curry (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DhxBcPJr1igtHNqDyvJ_lA?select=rXou2_qIHgPBpQ_w3t4lJw): How can I say no to a name like that? Red curry with spinach, cabbage, bell pepper, bamboo shoot, coconut milk and choice of beef. The beef was a bit tough, but the curry was perfect. Great balance of coconut milk in the curry. The spiciness was there but didn't burn my tongue or stomach eating it.

Chef Pai's BBQ Chicken (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DhxBcPJr1igtHNqDyvJ_lA?select=kcVpkgDoAg-QuTbdDI0oJA): Chicken roasted in a honey lemongrass curry marinade. The skin was so flavorful. Big meaty bites of deliciousness! Both of the dipping sauces were very good. One was a sweet tangy chili sauce and the other had more savory and smoky taste to it. 

It seems like Jitlada has a lot of regulars. Customers were greeted by name and people called in for their usual. Great little spot.
author: Marti L.

description:
A friend took me here for dinner quite awhile ago so this is a long overdue review. 

I have to say this is the best Thai restaurant I've ever eaten at. I love Thai food and have so far been spoiled by good Thai restaurants.
The difference between this place and other places is the freshness of the ingredients and the flavors. I ordered the eggplant and a pumpkin curry to share with my friend. Those are my usual favorites at Thai places. The pumpkin curry is the best one I've had by far. I don't know how they do it, but there's just more depth in the flavor that makes it really good. The eggplant was also really good. I could tell the eggplant was very fresh from biting into it.
The head chef was super nice and gave my friend and me an appetizer on the house.

My friend and I were crazy stupid full by the end of dinner but we felt horrible for not finishing our plates of food. So we sat there eating and sobbing about how full we were but also that the food was too good to waste.

I unfortunately do not live near SF, otherwise I'd come here more often.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I was visiting San Francisco for the weekend and was staying nearby so my girlfriend and I decided to try this place because it had overall good reviews. As soon as we entered, we were greeted by a really bad smell but we decided to stay anyway, we ordered the Pumpkin curry, white sticky rice and their Thai tea. The tea was really good but the food was awful!!! The White sticky rice was super bland and dry and the curry was tasteless, but the absolute worst part of all was that when I bit into the chicken in my curry it was NOT FULLY COOKED and pink in the middle. They are really thin strips of chicken so I don't understand how you mess that up. I immediately gagged and pushed it away. When I went to say something, our server asked, "Do you want a to go box?" And I said "actually no..." and before I could get another word out she turned around and grabbed our check and placed it on the table. I know she knew I had more to say but didn't want to hear it. I paid for the food and left. We were probably in there for a total of 25 minutes, I was so disgusted by this place. The service was awful and the food was even worse!!! If you want to spend the entire night dry heaving and potentially catch salmonella definitely try this place!
author: Gabriela B.

description:
I live about one block away so this is my go-to thai restaurant. the inside is definitely really small, only seats about 20-25 people max i wanna say. another strange thing: the bathroom is like far. like really far. like past the kitchen into a whole separate room far.

HOWEVER, the food is pretty good! nothing exceptional, but definitely a nice place to have amongst all the japanese options in the area. i would really got it a 3.5, but 4 seems too generous. i really enjoyed the pad see ew here, and the pad thai was good as well just not exceptional. my friend had the curry and said it was good but i cant say for sure! prices were pretty fair, all around 10-15 dollars a plate which is pretty standard for a thai place.
author: Thach N.

description:
I am not impressed. :/ Found this place while searching for "Northern Thai." Nothing about it was Northern Thai, which is fine, as long as the food is good. But the food was all very typical, and what really bothered me the most is how SWEET everything was.

I understand they're trying to cater to the "American" taste buds, but come on, LOADS of sugar is the last thing I want in my extra extra spicy tom yum goong.

But I am still giving two stars because the ladies who work there are just too sweet.
author: Susie S.

description:
We get takeout from Jitlada every now and then... my wife loves their red curry. The food overall is quite good and reliable, and won't break the bank. I've had most of their curries, and had the eggplant/basil dish recently, which was delicious.

The restaurant itself is also nice inside, on a quiet street just north of Japantown. The service is friendly, and the owner is kind of a hoot. I recommend giving them a try.
author: Andrew M.

description: Black rice mango desert is DA BOMB. Ahaha It's that good. Pumpkin curry was awesome too, worth getting if you've never had pumpkin curry (like me!)
author: Christopher M.

description: Their Pad Kee Mao was the best Ive ever had, and I go to a lot of Thai food places. I would go once a week if I didnt have to drive all the way to the city to get it.
author: Rheanne O.

description:
Wow!  I am totally in love with Jitlada SF!! If you can make down to Japantown and try this Thai restaurant you will not be sorry.  I travel to SF from LA all the time and make it point to eat here every visit sometimes twice, if not three times. 

The couple that owns the restaurant Ray and Pai are the sweetest people ever.  Pai the head Chef should get more attention from SF locals than she is currently getting now. 

They are open for lunch and dinner.  I recommend the coconut sticky rice to accommodate any curry.  What can I say it blows my hair back.
author: Jane D.

description: Pumpkin curry and ginger shrimp rolls are heavenly. We love this place and get take out all the time. Staff is friendly and hard working. Best Thai food in the area.
author: Lindsay U.

description:
I came here for dinner and I got to try...
- Stuffed Basil Eggplant: This appetizer is decent... I wouldn't order it again, but some of my friends seemed to have enjoyed it.
- Som Tom (Papaya Salad): I liked this the least out of everything that we ordered... I don't know why people like papaya salads in general.
- Pad Thai: pretty good!! it's sweeter (and less peanut-y) than the ones that I've had at other thai restaurants.
- Fried rice: I don't remember if we got chicken or beef with it, but it was good. I can't really tell the different between fried rice from different restaurants, so the fried rice here was like any other fried rice (in my opinion).
- Pumpkin Curry: DELICIOUS. wow. I was hesitant about getting this curry because I don't like pumpkin... but it was so so so so so good!!! Wowowowowow I would come back here just for the pumpkin curry. 

tl;dr...GET THE PUMPKIN CURRY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Annie S.

description:
got take ot here a few times

crying tiger and bankok with chicken salads both really good - ask for no fish sauce
author: Jon K.

description: The owners are very nice but I ordered a rice noodle dish that I swear was barela pasta. It was take out so there was nothing I could do about it. I'm allergic to wheat so that sucked. The shrimp appetizer was delicious but that was all I could eat. Also the meat and the noodle dish that I managed to fish out was very tough. I wish I could give a better review.
author: Sabra b.

description: This place is usually very good.  The curries are great and the basil entrees are also good.  Occasionally take out takes awhile, but with the wait of it does.
author: Shawn C.

description: There was a very pleasant atmosphere. We had An authentic Thai food experience! It was extremely tasty and delicious!! The waitress was very nice and kind. As well the owner of the restaurant was really lovely! Highly recommended!!!!
author: Meital B.

description: This is my favorite Thai spot in the city! The staff are really friendly and they greet me using my name and they know my order. My favorite dish is the pumpkin curry with tofu. SO yummy!
author: Corina J.

description: My boyfriend and I decided to get take-out here since the reviews were so high. I ordered the pumpkin curry with chicken (doesn't come with rice) and he had the pad kee mao. I felt that my pumpkin curry was a little on the saltier side, but my boyfriend really liked his pad kee mao. It was spicy for me, but the veggies and meat they had was delicious. I will come back to try dining in next time and hope for a better experience for me to update this review.
author: Amanda C.

description: Been open for 15 years and absolute neighborhood gem. Great flavorful Thai, one of best in SF. Solid prices
author: Evan K.

description: Our favorite neighborhood Thai restaurant.  I recommend the mango sticky rice for dessert and I've had most everything in their menu.  The pumpkin curry, spicy eggplant, salads are my favorites.  Great service and ambiance.
author: Nise c.

description:
Jitlada is easily one of the better Thai restaurants in SF - tasty, authentic food at great prices. The only regret I have is not asking for spicier. 

I went here on a Wednesday after work with a friend, we ordered the Ginger Shrimp roll and the Chicken Satay to start. The Chicken Satay is large skewers of chicken with peanut sauce, I was pretty impressed by the quality of meat.  

The Evil Princess curry is a spicy red curry, definitely seemed to be a popular choice. Of course, a meal with only one curry is not a meal, so we also tried the Gaeng Keaw Wan (green curry) with Chicken. This was easily my favorite dish of the night, extremely flavorful with green beans and eggplant. I can still taste it now!
